metadata.case_name: Appellant (Tenant) v. Respondents (including Allottee, Landlords, and Assistant Rent Control Officer)

facts.text: The appellant is the tenant and respondents Nos. 2 and 3 are the landlords of a non-residential accommodation in a part of a building in Mohalla Bulanala in the city of Varanasi. Respondent No. 1 is the allottee of the accommodation. Respondent No. 5 is the Assistant Rent Control and Eviction Officer, Varanasi, authorised by the District Magistrate to perform his functions under the U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947.
On February 11, 1956 the landlords obtained a decree for ejectment of the tenant from the accommodation.
On January 5, 1957, the landlords stated before respondent No. 5 in writing that the accommodation was about to be vacated by the tenant.
On January 22, 1957, the tenant stated before respondent No. 5 in writing that he was going to leave the accommodation in a month's time.
On February 12, 1957, the tenant made a statement before respondent No. 5 that he wanted to vacate the shop as the decree for ejectment had been passed against him.
On February 20, 1957, respondent No. 5 passed an order under s.7(2) of the Act directing the landlords to let the accommodation to respondent No. 1.

On February 22, 1957, the landlords and the tenant agreed that the tenant would continue to occupy the accommodation at an enhanced rent and would be liable to eviction in execution of the decree for ejectment in the event of his failing to pay the outstanding arrears of rent in certain stated instalments.
On February 23, 1957, proceedings were started against the appellant under s.7A(1) of the Act.
By an order dated March 23, 1957, under s.7A(2), respondent No. 5 directed the tenant to vacate the accommodation by March 24, 1957.

As the tenant failed to pay the agreed instalments of rent, on May 21, 1957, the landlords in execution of the decree for ejectment obtained an order from the executing court for the issue of a warrant for delivery of possession.
By an order dated December 2, 1957, under s.7A(3), respondent No. 5 directed O. P. S. Chowk to evict the tenant and put the allottee in occupation of the accommodation.

The tenant filed a writ petition challenging the orders of respondent No. 5. The writ petition was dismissed and the tenant was relegated to a suit. A special appeal from this order filed by the tenant was also dismissed.
On September 9, 1958, the tenant filed a suit asking for a declaration that the orders passed by respondent No. 5 were without jurisdiction and for consequential reliefs.
The trial court dismissed the suit. The appellate court reversed this decree and decreed the suit. On second appeal, the High Court restored the decree of the trial court and dismissed the suit.
The appellant was granted special leave to appeal to this Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the District Magistrate had power to pass the order of allotment under s.7(2) till the accommodation had fallen vacant.
Whether the order under s.7(2) would take effect only when the accommodation fell vacant.
Whether the proceedings under s.7A were without jurisdiction as there was no contravention of the order under s.7(2).

petitioner_arguments.text: The District Magistrate had no power to pass the order of allotment under s.7(2) unless the accommodation is or has fallen vacant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.7(2) of the U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if he had the power, the order would take effect only when the accommodation fell vacant.
The proceedings under s.7A were without jurisdiction as there was no contravention of the order under s.7(2), since the tenant was in occupation before the order.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.7A of the Act; Ram Lal v. Shiv Mani Singh

court_reasoning.text: The District Magistrate can pass an order under s.7(2) not only when the accommodation is or has fallen vacant but also when it is about to fall vacant. In the present case both the landlord and the tenant had made statements that the accommodation was about to fall vacant. On the materials on the record there could be no doubt that the accommodation was about to fall vacant when the District Magistrate passed the order under s.7(2).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accommodation was about to fall vacant based on statements and ejectment decree.

court_reasoning.text: The order under s.7(2) directed the landlords to let the accommodation to the allottee. The order took effect immediately. It could not be said that the order would take effect only when the accommodation actually fell vacant.

After the allotment was passed, the landlords agreed to accept the appellant as a tenant at enhanced rent. This letting and the continuance of occupation by the appellant under it were in direct breach of the allotment order. There was thus a contravention of the order and the District Magistrate had therefore jurisdiction to initiate proceedings under sub-section (1) of s.7A and to pass the orders under sub-sections (2) & (3) of s.7A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Post-allotment agreement constituted occupation in contravention; distinguished broad statement in Ram Lal case, referred to A.K. Khandelwal.

holdings.text: District Magistrate can pass order under s.7(2) when accommodation is about to fall vacant.
Order under s.7(2) takes effect immediately.
Post-allotment letting to tenant at enhanced rent constitutes contravention, justifying s.7A proceedings.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Lal v. Shiv Mani Singh and others
precedents_cited.relevance: Disagreed with broad statement that continuance of pre-allotment occupation cannot be contravention.

precedents_cited.case_name: A. K. Khandelwal v. Moti Lal Chawla and others
precedents_cited.relevance: It is a question of fact whether pre-allotment occupant contravened order.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Temporary Control of Rent and Eviction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs allotment orders when accommodation about to fall vacant, effect of such orders, and proceedings for contravention.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upholding the High Court's restoration of the trial court's dismissal of the suit, confirming the validity and jurisdiction of the orders under s.7(2) and s.7A passed by the Assistant Rent Control and Eviction Officer.

key_quotes.text: The District Magistrate can pass an order under s.7(2) not only when the accommodation is or has fallen vacant but also when it is about to fall vacant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of s.7(2) power.

key_quotes.text: This letting and the continuance of occupation by the appellant under it were in direct breach of the allotment order.
key_quotes.speaker: court
